d="M90 112c-6.62 0-12-5.38-12-12s5.38-12 12-12 12 5.38 12 12-5.38 12-12 12zM24 76c-6.62 0-12-5.38-12-12s5.38-12 12-12 12 5.38 12 12-5.38 12-12 12zm66-60c6.62 0 12 5.38 12 12s-5.38 12-12 12-12-5.38-12-12 5.38-12 12-12zm0 62c-6.56 0-12.44 2.9-16.48 7.48L45.1 70.2c.58-1.98.9-4.04.9-6.2s-.32-4.22-.9-6.2l28.42-15.28C77.56 47.1 83.44 50 90 50c12.14 0 22-9.86 22-22S102.14 6 90 6s-22 9.86-22 22c0 1.98.28 3.9.78 5.72L40.14 49.1C36.12 44.76 30.38 42 24 42 11.86 42 2 51.86 2 64s9.86 22 22 22c6.38 0 12.12-2.76 16.14-7.12l28.64 15.38c-.5 1.84-.78 3.76-.78 5.74 0 12.14 9.86 22 22 22s22-9.86 22-22-9.86-22-22-22z"></path></svg><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Share</span></span></button></div></div></div><div class="ExportCitation u-display-inline-block" id="export-citation"><div class="popover export-citation-popover" id="export-citation-popover"><div id="popover-trigger-export-citation-popover"><button class="button-link button-link-secondary button-link-icon-left button-link-has-colored-icon" type="button" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="true"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 104 128" height="20" class="icon icon-cited-by-66"><path d="M2 58.78V106h44V64H12v-5.22C12 40.28 29.08 32 46 32V22C20.1 22 2 37.12 2 58.78zM102 32V22c-25.9 0-44 15.12-44 36.78V106h44V64H68v-5.22C68 40.28 85.08 32 102 32z"></path></svg><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Cite</span></span></button></div></div></div></div></div><div class="ArticleIdentifierLinks u-margin-xs-bottom text-xs" id="article-identifier-links"><a class="anchor doi anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jpowsour.2025.236171" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener" aria-label="Persistent link using digital object identifier" title="Persistent link using digital object identifier"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jpowsour.2025.236171</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor rights-and-content anchor-primary" href="https://s100.copyright.com/AppDispatchServlet?publisherName=ELS&amp;contentID=S0378775325000072&amp;orderBeanReset=true" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Get rights and content</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div><div class="LicenseInfo text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author-highlights" id="abs0020" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Highlights</h2><div id="abssec0020"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0020"><ul class="list"><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0010">Volume expansion of GeP in lithi- or sodi-ation leads to poor mechanical properties of GeP electrode.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0015">The volume expansion is the main reason for the low initial CE.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0020">GeP/SWCNTs composite anode delivered the outstanding initial CE of ∼85 % in LIBs, and ∼90 % in SIBs.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0025">GeP/SWCNTs composite alleviate expansion in the first lithiation/sodiation.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0030">Mixing SWCNTs strengthed GeP electrodes' robustness and uniform Li<sup>+</sup> and Na<sup>+</sup> ion diffusion.</div></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="abstract author" id="abs0010" lang="en"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="abssec0010"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010">Layered germanium phosphide (GeP) is considered a promising anode material for lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) and sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to its high specific capacity and rapid Li<sup>+</sup>/Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion. Herein, we first reveal that the pristine GeP nanosheet shows ∼110&nbsp;% and 128&nbsp;% volume expansion during the first lithiation/sodiation by <em>in-situ</em> transmission electron microscopy (TEM), respectively, which leads to severe detectable fractures or cracks of the GeP anode. Thus, we revisit the failure mechanism of the GeP anode is attributed to the unsatisfactory mechanical robustness. Then, we propose a simple and efficient strategy that combines GeP nanosheets with single-walled carbon nanotubes (SWCNTs) to design a GeP/SWCNTs composite anode. Nanoindentation experiments and theoretical calculations confirm that the GeP/SWCNTs composite exhibits reduced internal stress to alleviate expansion in the first lithiation/sodiation. As a result, the GeP/SWCNTs composite anode delivers an initial Coulombic efficiency of ∼85&nbsp;% and ∼90&nbsp;% in LIBs and SIBs, respectively. More importantly, the specific capacity retentions are improved from ∼11&nbsp;% and ∼8&nbsp;% after 50 cycles to ∼50&nbsp;% and ∼51&nbsp;% remarkably after 200 cycles in LIBs and SIBs, respectively.</div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="abs0015"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphical abstract</h2><div id="abssec0015"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0015"><span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="undfig1"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775325000072-ga1.jpg" height="200" alt="Image 1"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775325000072-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (298KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (298KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775325000072-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775325000084"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775325000114"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="kwrds0010" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="kwrd0010" class="keyword"><span>Germanium phosphide</span></div><div id="kwrd0015" class="keyword"><span>Lithium/sodium-ion batteries</span></div><div id="kwrd0020" class="keyword"><span>Mechanical robustness</span></div><div id="kwrd0025" class="keyword"><span>Single-walled carbon nanotubes</span></div><div id="kwrd0030" class="keyword"><span>Initial coulombic efficiency</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="sec1"><h2 id="sectitle0035" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0040">Energy storage devices are key to making the best use of clean energy and reducing the consumption of fossil fuels [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib1" name="bbib1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">1</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib2" name="bbib2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2</span></span></a>]. Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) are prominent among rechargeable batteries owing to their high energy density and long-cycle stability, which have already been incorporated into portable electronic devices and electric cars [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib3" name="bbib3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">3</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib4" name="bbib4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">4</span></span></a>]. Considering the shortage of lithium resources and the high cost, alternative energy storage systems with low cost and abundant resources will become an urgent need for future applications. Since Na<sup>+</sup> is abundant on the earth and has similar chemical properties to Li<sup>+</sup>, more researchers are focusing on sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib5" name="bbib5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">5</span></span></a>]. The SIBs are regarded as a complementary technology to LIBs, potentially becoming the next generation of energy storage devices [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib6" name="bbib6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">6</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0045">Anodes play a crucial role in ion battery performance. In recent years, the anodes used for LIBs and SIBs have been mainly carbon-based materials [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib7" name="bbib7" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib7"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">7</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib8" name="bbib8" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib8"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">8</span></span></a>]. However, the capacity of these materials is relatively low. To meet the high-capacity requirements for LIBs and SIBs [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib9" name="bbib9" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib9"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">9</span></span></a>], anode materials with better performance are being developed. Metal phosphides have been explored as potential anodes for LIBs and SIBs [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib10" name="bbib10" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib10"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">10</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib11" name="bbib11" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib11"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">11</span></span></a>]. GeP is one of the typical materials among them [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib12" name="bbib12" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib12"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">12</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib13" name="bbib13" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib13"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>]. On the one hand, GeP has good conductivity owing to the increased conductivity of the Ge component compared to pure phosphorus [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib14" name="bbib14" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib14"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">14</span></span></a>]. The conductivity of GeP (50&nbsp;000&nbsp;S/cm<sup>2</sup>) is far higher than that of graphite [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib15" name="bbib15" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib15"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">15</span></span></a>]. On the other hand, the expansion of GeP during lithiation or sodiation is also much lower than that of P. In addition, GeP resembles black P and graphite in a unique layered structure, which is believed to be very beneficial for Li<sup>+</sup>/Na<sup>+</sup> intercalation and deintercalation [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib16" name="bbib16" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib16"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">16</span></span></a>]. GeP serving as an anode material, delivers the expected theoretical capacity of 1900 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> and 1033 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> for LIBs and SIBs, respectively [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib17" name="bbib17" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib17"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">17</span></span></a>]. These advantages are considered very convincing for Li<sup>+</sup>/Na<sup>+</sup> storage. However, the electrochemical performance of a GeP as anode is not ideal in LIBs and SIBs, especially with an initial Coulombic efficiency (ICE) and cycling stability significantly lower than that of similar anodes.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0050">To enhance the electrochemical performance of the GeP anode, numerous related studies have been conducted [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib16" name="bbib16" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib16"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[16]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib17" name="bbib17" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib17"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[17]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib18" name="bbib18" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib18"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[18]</span></span></a>]. In our previous work, the lithium storage mechanism of GeP was investigated by <em>in-situ</em> TEM, and its cycling stability was improved by narrowing the voltage range. A recent study by Zeng et al. found that the hollow nitrogen-doped carbon fibres encapsulate GeP nanoreactors with a self-supported conductive network, which ensures sufficient electrolyte infiltration and fast electron transport, and accommodates the volume expansion of GeP simultaneously [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib18" name="bbib18" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib18"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>]. In addition. Tseng et al. discovered that mesoporous germanium phosphide microspheres composed of about 10&nbsp;nm nanoparticles with a narrow pore size distribution of about 4&nbsp;nm, which can shorten the diffusion path of energy carriers and provide buffer space for Li<sup>+</sup>/Na<sup>+</sup> transport [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib19" name="bbib19" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib19"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">19</span></span></a>]. Many factors affect the electrochemical performance of GeP, including the SEI layer, conductivity, mechanical properties, etc [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib20" name="bbib20" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib20"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib21" name="bbib21" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib21"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>]. The expansion of GeP nanosheets during charge-discharge cycles can lead to mechanical instability, resulting in a low ICE and rapid decay. Therefore, mechanical properties are one of the key factors influencing its electrochemical performance. It is necessary to study the relationship between the mechanical properties of the GeP electrode, its ICE and cycling stability, and take further measures to improve the mechanical properties of the GeP electrode during Li<sup>+</sup> or Na<sup>+</sup> insertion/extraction. At present, compositing with carbon-based materials (carbon nanotubes [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib22" name="bbib22" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib22"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">22</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib23" name="bbib23" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib23"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">23</span></span></a>], graphene [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib24" name="bbib24" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib24"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">24</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib25" name="bbib25" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib25"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">25</span></span></a>], reduced graphene oxide [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib26" name="bbib26" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib26"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">26</span></span></a>], nitrogen-doped porous carbon [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib27" name="bbib27" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib27"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib28" name="bbib28" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib28"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">28</span></span></a>], etc.) is a very effective method to improve the alloy-type anodes’ mechanical properties. For example, Li et al. found that a dual-carbon network of AB/GO was a good choice to improve the mechanical properties of GeP<sub>5</sub> as an anode material for SIBs [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib29" name="bbib29" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib29"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>]. However, among the carbon-based materials, compositing GeP with SWCNTs has more advantages in alleviating the stress caused by expansion for GeP electrodes [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib30" name="bbib30" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib30"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">30</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib31" name="bbib31" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib31"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">31</span></span></a>]. Consequently, the conductive network formed by SWCNTs provides pathways for the transport of electrons and ions. At the same time, the intertwined network structure can constrain GeP, enhancing the mechanical strength of the electrode [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib21" name="bbib21" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib21"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0055">In this study, we first investigate the failure mechanism of layered GeP in LIBs and SIBs comprehensively by <em>in-situ</em> TEM combined with ex-situ techniques [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib32" name="bbib32" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib32"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">32</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib33" name="bbib33" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib33"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">33</span></span></a>]. No cracks were found, indicating that individual GeP nanosheets can resist expansion after complete lithiation/sodiation. However, GeP nanosheets display about 110&nbsp;% and 128&nbsp;% area expansion. The expansion of GeP nanosheets resulted in a large number of cracks on the electrode during the prolonged cycles, further leading to a decrease in its mechanical performance. This directly presented a low ICE of GeP electrode, only ∼71&nbsp;% and ∼49&nbsp;% in LIBs and SIBs. The key to improving the ICE and stability of the GeP electrode is to effectively maintain its integrity during the cycles. Thus, GeP nanosheets can be mixed with SWCNT to improve their mechanical properties. The GeP/SWCNTs exhibited reduced internal stress and improved ion transport as shown by nanoindentation experiments and theoretical calculations. GeP/SWCNTs electrode delivered considerable Coulombic efficiency of approximately 85&nbsp;% and 90&nbsp;% in LIBs and SIBs, respectively. Beyond that, the cycling behaviour of GeP/SWCNTs electrode was greatly enhanced with capacity retention values of ∼50&nbsp;% and ∼51&nbsp;% after 200 cycles in LIBs and SIBs. The improvement in the performance of GeP/SWCNTs electrodes can be attributed to the efficient recombination of SWCNTs.</div></section><section id="sec2"><h2 id="sectitle0040" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental section</h2><section id="sec2.1"><h3 id="sectitle0045" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Materials synthesis</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0060">GeP/SWCNTs was prepared using the following steps. Firstly, bulk GeP was prepared by the specific procedures. Bulk GeP was exfoliated into few-layer GeP by sonicating for 2&nbsp;h under high-power at 1000&nbsp;W, which have been reported in our group's previous work [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib13" name="bbib13" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib13"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>]. SWCNTs were purchased from OCSiAl company (Russia). The corresponding SEM was shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S1</span></span></a>. Then the few-layer GeP was ground by hand with SWCNTs in an agate mortar for 30&nbsp;min at various proportions (9:1, 7:3, 1:1), dissolved in 150&nbsp;ml of ethanol, and sonicated in an ice bath at 800&nbsp;W for 30&nbsp;min [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib34" name="bbib34" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib34"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">34</span></span></a>]. The mixed 100&nbsp;mg of GeP/SWCNTs was centrifugated at 5000&nbsp;rpm for 20&nbsp;min. The supernatant was removed, and ethanol solution was added. The mixture was shaken, centrifuged, and the washing process was repeated three times. Finally, the GeP/SWCNTs were dried in a vacuum oven at 80&nbsp;°C for 20&nbsp;min.</div></section><section id="sec2.2"><h3 id="sectitle0050" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Cell assembly</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0065">Electrochemical lithium/sodium-storage was tested using a 2032 coin half-cell. The copper foil used as a current collector was coated with a slurry consisting of active materials (GeP or GeP/SWCNTs), conductive additives (Ketjenblack, KQ) and binders (Carboxymethyl cellulose, CMC) in a ratio of 7:2:1. Lithium/sodium foils serve as counter electrodes. Lithium hexafluorophosphate (LiPF<sub>6</sub> 1&nbsp;M) dissolved in a mixed solution containing ethylene carbonate (EC), dimethyl carbonate (DMC), and diethyl carbonate (DEC) with volume ratio (1:1:1), which is used for the electrolyte in LIBs. Sodium trifluomethanesulfonate(CF<sub>3</sub>NaO<sub>3</sub>S 1&nbsp;M) dissolved in tetraethylene glycol dimethyl ether (C<sub>10</sub>H<sub>22</sub>O<sub>5</sub>), which is used as SIBs’ electrolyte. Polypropylene (PP) and glassfiber were used as the separators for LIBs and SIBs, respectively. A coin-cell was assembled in a glove box with GeP or GeP/SWCNTs as the anode (with a loading mass of 1.5–2&nbsp;mg&nbsp;cm<sup>−2</sup>).</div></section><section id="sec2.3"><h3 id="sectitle0055" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Material characterization</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0070">Performance was tested at 25&nbsp;°C on LAND instruments (LAND CT2001A) and workstation (Solartron 1470E). Sample morphology and components of materials were characterized by a field-Semission scanning electron microscope (SEM, Hitachi-S4800), an aberration-corrected scanning/transmission electron microscope (ACS/TEM, JEM ARM 200F), X-ray diffraction (XRD, Cu Ka1 radiation, λ&nbsp;=&nbsp;1.5418&nbsp;Å), and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Fisher Esca Lab 250Xi at a 0.1 angle of emission, Al Kα, 1486.6&nbsp;eV). The dynamic area change of single GeP nanosheet was analyzed by an electrochemical holder (Zhejiang University), which is similar to previous successful reports.</div></section><section id="sec2.4"><h3 id="sectitle0060" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.4. Nanoindentation experiment</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0075">Nanomechanical investigations were conducted with a NanoTest Vantage system provided by Micro Materials Ltd. The berkovich tripyramidal indenter is utilized, with a blunt radius of 100&nbsp;nm. The measurements were conducted at room temperature. Three test points were selected for each sample. Loading, holding and unloading times were 25, 5, and 10&nbsp;s, respectively. The data can be obtained to plot the load-displacement curve and use the curve to calculate the elastic modulus of the material. The elastic modulus <em>E</em><sub><em>IT</em></sub> of the tested sample can be calculated as follows:<span class="display"><span id="ufd1" class="formula"><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-1-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mrow transform="translate(369,-159)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use></g></g></g></g></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">I</mi><mi is="true">T</mi></mrow></msub><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true"><mfrac is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">r</mi><mi is="true">e</mi></mrow></msub></mfrac><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">2</mn></msubsup></mrow><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">i</mi></msub></mfrac></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-1"><math><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">I</mi><mi is="true">T</mi></mrow></msub><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">=</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">−</mo><msup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow><mrow is="true"><mfrac is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">r</mi><mi is="true">e</mi></mrow></msub></mfrac><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">−</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo linebreak="badbreak" is="true">−</mo><msubsup is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi><mi is="true">i</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msubsup></mrow><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">i</mi></msub></mfrac></mrow></mfrac></mrow></math></script></span></span></span>where <em>E</em><sub><em>re</em></sub> is the reduced modulus, <em>V</em> is the Poisson ratio of the sample, <em>E</em><sub><em>i</em></sub> and <em>V</em><sub><em>i</em></sub> are the elastic modulus and Poisson's ratio of diamond indenter, respectively, <em>E</em><sub><em>i</em></sub>&nbsp;=&nbsp;1140&nbsp;GPa, <em>V</em><sub><em>i</em></sub>&nbsp;=&nbsp;0.07 [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib31" name="bbib31" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib31"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">31</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib32" name="bbib32" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib32"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">32</span></span></a>] [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib35" name="bbib35" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib35"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">35</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib36" name="bbib36" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib36"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">36</span></span></a>]. By calculation, the elastic modulus of the samples with/without SWCNTs are about 255&nbsp;GPa and 233&nbsp;GPa, respectively. This means that samples with SWCNTs are more resistant to deformation during charging.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0080">FEM model: A 2D FEM model is established by COMSOL Multi-physics software to further study the mechanical-chemical characteristic of the anode. The anode samples are assumed as an isotropic homogeneous material. The Li<sup>+</sup>/Na<sup>+</sup> transport process is realized through the dilute matter transfer module. Combined with the solid mechanics module, the deformation of the anode during charging process can be studied. Based on the above experimental data, the elastic modulus of the samples with/without SWCNTs are setting as 255&nbsp;GPa and 233&nbsp;GPa, respectively.</div></section></section><section id="sec3"><h2 id="sectitle0065" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><section id="sec3.1"><h3 id="sectitle0070" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.1. Revealing the failure mechanism of layered GeP anode</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0085">As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>a and d, the GeP electrode exhibited an initial high specific capacity of 1024/1435&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> and 403/819&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> with the corresponding CE of 71&nbsp;% and 49&nbsp;% for LIBs and SIBs, respectively. The first CE of GeP as anode was poor, especially in SIBs. Thus, it can be predicted that the cycling durability of the original GeP electrode was also unsatisfactory. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>b, the capacity retention of the electrode was ∼11&nbsp;% after 50 cycles in LIBs. In addition, the capacity retention of GeP electrode was also poor in SIBs with only ∼8&nbsp;% after 50 cycles in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>e. The method of limiting discharge capacity was applied to explore the electrochemical performance of GeP electrodes in both LIBs and SIBs [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib37" name="bbib37" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib37"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">37</span></span></a>]. The charge capacity remained almost 100&nbsp;%, 97&nbsp;% and 86&nbsp;% after 10 cycles by limiting the discharge capacity to 400, 600 and 900&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, respectively in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>c. However, the GeP electrode was less stable in SIBs than in LIBs. The charge capacity remained almost 97&nbsp;%, 52&nbsp;% and 26&nbsp;% after 5 cycles when the discharge capacity was limited to 400, 600 and 800 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, respectively in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig1" name="bfig1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a>f. Whether in LIBs or SIBs, the stability of the GeP electrode was significantly improved as the discharge capacity decreased. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S2</span></span></a> showed the impedances of the GeP electrode became better with the reduction of the limiting capacity. It indicated that the GeP electrode was more severely damaged due to the intercalation/deintercalation of abundant Li<sup>+</sup>/Na<sup>+</sup>. The results revealed once again that the poor electrochemical performance of GeP generally originates from expansion due to the insertion and expulsion of a large number of ions.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig1"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775325000072-gr1.jpg" height="386" alt="Fig. 1" aria-describedby="cap0010"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775325000072-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (966KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (966KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775325000072-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0010"><p id="fspara0010"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. (a, b) The first three discharge/charge and cycling stability curves of GeP electrode at 0.1&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> in the 0.005–3&nbsp;V range in LIBs, respectively. (d, e) The first three discharge/charge and cycling stability curves of GeP electrode at 0.1&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> with the 0.005–3&nbsp;V in SIBs, respectively. (c) The cycling performance with the limiting discharge capacities of 400, 600 and 900&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> in LIBs. (f) The cycling performance with discharge capacities of 400, 600 and 800&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> in SIBs.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0090">Understanding the mechanical robustness of the GeP anode is crucial for improving its electrochemical performance in LIBs or SIBs within an actual battery cell. The solid-state battery device inside the <em>in-situ</em> TEM is shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S3</span></span></a>. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>a–d showed the typical morphological evolutions of individual GeP nanosheets during lithiation and sodiation by <em>in-situ</em> TEM [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib38" name="bbib38" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib38"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">38</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib39" name="bbib39" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib39"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">39</span></span></a>]. There were no noticeable cracks or fractures in GeP nanosheet. This indicated that GeP nanosheets possess the ability to resist expansion during Li<sup>+</sup>/Na<sup>+</sup> storage. The original width of 462&nbsp;nm significantly expanded to 489&nbsp;nm after full lithiation at the same marked position, resulting in a total area expansion of approximately 110&nbsp;%. Furthermore, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>c and d showed that the marked length of 113&nbsp;nm expanded to 144&nbsp;nm with a total area expansion of 128&nbsp;% after full sodiation. Our previous studies have demonstrated that GeP stores more ions during lithiation than during sodiation. However, the larger radius of Na⁺ results in a more significant area expansion of GeP during lithiation compared to sodiation. The area expansion of GeP in the alloying process far exceeded that in the intercalation process [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib12" name="bbib12" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib12"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">12</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib13" name="bbib13" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib13"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>]. In addition, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>e and f, multiple cracks were observed in GeP electrodes after 10 cycles in ex-situ SEM due to the expansion of individual GeP nanosheets. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S4</span></span></a> showed that the viscosity of GeP electrode is poor after lithiation or sodiation, and GeP easily detached from the copper foil in lithiation. As exhibited in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig2" name="bfig2" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig2"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a>g, this expansion caused GeP nanosheets to lose contact with other media and current collectors, resulting in the destruction of GeP electrode framework during charge and discharge cycles in the cell. It led to poor mechanical robustness. The primary reason for electrode failure is attributed to a low initial coulombic efficiency.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig2"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775325000072-gr2.jpg" height="674" alt="Fig. 2" aria-describedby="cap0015"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775325000072-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (2MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775325000072-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0015"><p id="fspara0015"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. (a, b) The evolution of the morphology of individual GeP in lithiation by <em>in-situ</em> TEM. (c, d) The evolution of the morphology of individual GeP in sodiation by <em>in-situ</em> TEM. (e, f) The morphology of the GeP electrode after 10 cycles of lithiation and sodiation, respectively. (g) Diagram of electrode failure process.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="sec3.2"><h3 id="sectitle0075" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.2. The enhancement of mechanical robustness through incorporating SWCNTs</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0095">Compared with the high-temperature and high-pressure methods, simple mixing by ultrasonication is less likely to damage the original GeP. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>b and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S5</span></span></a>, the GeP nanosheets were small and uniform, rich in germanium and phosphorus, and uniformly distributed on the surface without any other elements, as confirmed by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX). <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>a and c revealed that the surface of the GeP/SWCNTs electrode exhibits a typical morphology of SWCNTs. The GeP nanosheets are well-dispersed within the carbon matrix, creating a three-dimensional network that supports the GeP nanosheets in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S6</span></span></a> and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S7</span></span></a>. This structure provided the GeP/SWCNTs electrode with superior resistance to expansion. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>d demonstrated that the GeP nanosheet has an ultrathin and transparent lamellar shape within the GeP/SWCNTs. The marked diffraction spots in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>e can be attributed to the (−20-1), (1–11), and (-1-10) planes, respectively. The HRTEM images in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>f showed parallel lattice fringes corresponding to the (201) planes, with a d-spacing of 5.19&nbsp;Å for GeP, consistent with the SAED pattern viewed along the same zone axis. These results indicate that GeP retained its original structure and no new phases were formed after the creation of GeP/SWCNTs. The pristine GeP and GeP/SWCNTs composite exhibited sharp diffraction peaks at 13.9°, 21.1°, and 26.8°, corresponding to the GeP (20-1), (20-2), and (111) planes, as shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>g and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S8</span></span></a> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib12" name="bbib12" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib12"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">12</span></span></a>]. The impedance of the GeP/SWCNTs electrode was lower than that of the GeP electrode, as illustrated in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>h, indicating that SWCNTs contributed to enhancing the electronic conductivity of GeP. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig3" name="bfig3" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig3"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>i presents a comparison of Young's modulus for the GeP electrode and the GeP/SWCNTs electrode. The GeP electrode containing SWCNTs demonstrates a higher Young's modulus. The conductive network formed by SWCNTs reduces the strain experienced by GeP under unit stress, resulting in greater resistance to deformation during the charge/discharge processes of the GeP electrode [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib40" name="bbib40" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib40"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">40</span></span></a>]. The incorporation of GeP/SWCNTs significantly enhances the mechanical toughness of the entire electrode while also effectively controlling the discharge capacity and improving electrical conductivity.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig3"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775325000072-gr3.jpg" height="606" alt="Fig. 3" aria-describedby="cap0020"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775325000072-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775325000072-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0020"><p id="fspara0020"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. (a) Structure model of GeP/SWCNTs. (b) SEM of GeP nanosheets. (c) SEM of GeP/SWCNTs. (d) Low-resolution TEM of GeP nanosheets in the GeP/SWCNTs. (e) Selective diffraction (SAED) of GeP. (f) High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) of GeP nanosheets corresponding to SAED pattern. (g) XRD patterns of GeP/SWCNTs. (h) Impedance of both GeP electrode and GeP/SWCNTs electrode. (i) Evolution of Young's modulus at three different points for GeP electrode and GeP/SWCNTs electrode.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="sec3.3"><h3 id="sectitle0080" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.3. The theoretical analysis of mechanical properties for GeP/SWCNTs composite</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0100">A 2D FEM model is established by COMSOL Multiphysics software to further study the mechanical properties of GeP/SWCNTs anode in lithiation/sodiation. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>a–c (lithiation) and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>a–c (sodiation), GeP anode with SWCNTs exhibits better ion transport properties, leading to a higher diffusion coefficient. Therefore, the ion distribution along the thickness direction of the GeP/SWCNTs electrode is more uniform [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib36" name="bbib36" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib36"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">36</span></span></a>]. The result is consistent with the analysis of impedance comparison. The distribution of Li<sup>+</sup> or Na<sup>+</sup> in the electrode has an important effect on its internal stress in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>d–f and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>d–f. The internal ion distribution of the electrode is more uniform, resulting in lower diffusion stress and improved mechanical properties. This also means enhanced ion transport properties, increased resistance to expansion deformation, and reduced internal stress [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib35" name="bbib35" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib35"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">35</span></span></a>]. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig4" name="bfig4" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig4"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>g–i and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig5" name="bfig5" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig5"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>g–i showed that the displacement of GeP/SWCNTs anode is also smaller, which further confirms that SWCNTs have a constraining effect on the lithiation/sodiation process of GeP at the same depth, reducing the overall expansion of the electrode. Overall, mixing with SWCNTs can significantly enhance the mechanical properties of the GeP electrode, thereby improving its ability to store Li<sup>+</sup> and Na<sup>+</sup>.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig4"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775325000072-gr4.jpg" height="520" alt="Fig. 4" aria-describedby="cap0025"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775325000072-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (918KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (918KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775325000072-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0025"><p id="fspara0025"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. (a–c) Evolution of concentration distribution of GeP and GeP/SWCNTs electrode at 1000&nbsp;s, 2000&nbsp;s, 3600. (d–f) Evolution of equivalent stress of GeP and GeP/SWCNTs electrode at 1000&nbsp;s, 2000&nbsp;s, 3600&nbsp;s. (g–i) Evolution of displacement comparison of GeP and GeP/SWCNTs electrode at 1000&nbsp;s, 2000&nbsp;s, and 3600&nbsp;s.</p></span></span></figure><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig5"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775325000072-gr5.jpg" height="535" alt="Fig. 5" aria-describedby="cap0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775325000072-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (1MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (1MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775325000072-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0030"><p id="fspara0030"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. (a–c) Evolution of concentration distribution of GeP and GeP/SWCNTs electrode at 1000&nbsp;s, 2000&nbsp;s, and 3600&nbsp;s respectively. (d–f) Evolution of equivalent stress of GeP and GeP/SWCNTs electrode at 1000&nbsp;s, 2000&nbsp;s, 3600&nbsp;s. (g–i) Evolution of displacement comparison of GeP and GeP/SWCNTs electrode at 1000&nbsp;s, 2000&nbsp;s, and 3600&nbsp;s.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="sec3.4"><h3 id="sectitle0085" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.4. The electrochemical performance of GeP/SWCNTs electrode</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0105">The electrochemical properties of GeP/SWCNTs were tested in LIBs and SIBs. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>a, the first discharge curve showed obvious platforms in the ranges of 0.75-0.45&nbsp;V, and 0.1–0.3&nbsp;V. The first discharge/charge curve also displayed two platforms in the range of 0.79-0.45&nbsp;V and 0.3–0.01&nbsp;V in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>d, respectively. These platforms indicated the formation of SEI and alloying process, which have been verified in previous work [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib13" name="bbib13" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib13"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">13</span></span></a>]. In addition, the rate capability of the GeP/SWCNTs electrode was also explored in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>b and 6e. The reversible capacities of 633, 429, 307, and 198&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> were obtained at current densities of 0.2, 1, 2, and 4&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, respectively in LIBs. When the current density returned to 0.2&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, the capacity also returned to 520&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>. Similarly, GeP/SWCNTs electrode could still achieve 80&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> at 4&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> in SIBs. When the current density dropped to 0.2&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>, the specific capacity returned to 354&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>. The results implied that the GeP/SWCNTs electrode still maintained a stable structure in charge-discharge cycles at a high rate.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig6"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775325000072-gr6.jpg" height="374" alt="Fig. 6" aria-describedby="cap0035"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775325000072-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (746KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (746KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S0378775325000072-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0035"><p id="fspara0035"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. (a, d) The potential profiles of GeP/SWCNTs electrodes in the first two cycles in LIBs and SIBs with a potential range of 0.005–3&nbsp;V. (b, e) The rate capability of GeP/SWCNTs electrode at 0.2, 1, 2 and 4&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> in LIBs and SIBs. (c, f) The cycling stability of GeP/SWCNTs electrode in LIBs and SIBs at 0.1&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup>.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110">Moreover, the cyclic stability of the GeP/SWCNTs electrode was significantly improved compared to the bare GeP electrode. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S9</span></span></a> showed that GeP/SWCNTs electrodes tended to be more stable with the increase in SWCNTs content in LIBs and SIBs. With a ratio of 7:3 between GeP and SWCNTs (GeP loading mass: 1.1–1.4&nbsp;mg&nbsp;cm<sup>−2</sup>), the electrode demonstrated optimal performance, striking a balance between the specific capacity and stability of the electrodes. As depicted in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>c, the GeP/SWCNTs electrode achieved a high CE of 85&nbsp;% and a specific capacity of 778/911 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> in LIBs. The electrochemical curve for the GeP/SWCNTs electrode tended to stabilize, and the specific capacity remained at 456 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> after 200 cycles. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig6" name="bfig6" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig6"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>f showed that the GeP/SWCNTs electrode delivered a considerable initial specific capacity of 719/793&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> and Coulombic efficiency of approximately 90&nbsp;% in SIBs. The obtained capacity was still high and reached 397&nbsp;mA&nbsp;h&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> after 200 cycles. The cyclability at high current density is shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S10</span></span></a>.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0115">The lithiation/sodiation reaction processes of GeP/SWCNTs anodes were further confirmed by the XPS. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S11a</span></span></a> showed two sets of binding energies of 126.8&nbsp;eV, 133.2&nbsp;eV and 127.8&nbsp;eV, 133.1&nbsp;eV [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib41" name="bbib41" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib41"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">41</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib42" name="bbib42" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib42"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">42</span></span></a>]. The binding energies were identified by the two phases of Li<sub>3</sub>P, Li<sub>a</sub>PO<sub>b</sub> and the phases of Na<sub>3</sub>P, and Na<sub>a</sub>PO<sub>b</sub>, respectively [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib37" name="bbib37" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib37"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">37</span></span></a>]. Li<sub>a</sub>PO<sub>b</sub> and Na<sub>a</sub>PO<sub>b</sub> were generated by the decomposition of electrolytes on the surface of GeP/SWCNTs [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib43" name="bbib43" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib43"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">43</span></span></a>]. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S11b</span></span></a>, the peaks at 29.6&nbsp;eV and 23.4&nbsp;eV were attributed to the binding energies of Li<sub>x</sub>Ge and Na<sub>x</sub>Ge, respectively on the basis of the reported articles [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib44" name="bbib44" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib44"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">44</span></span></a>]. The results were consistent with the CVs of GeP/SWCNTs in LIBs and SIBs. CVs showed an irreversible peak near 0.73&nbsp;V attributed to the formation of the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S12a</span></span></a>. The redox peaks at 0.04&nbsp;V and 0.46&nbsp;V corresponded to the alloying and dealloying of Li<sub>x</sub>Ge. The peaks around 0.42&nbsp;V and 0.86&nbsp;V could be attributed to the Li<sub>3</sub>P redox behaviour [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib45" name="bbib45" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib45"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">45</span></span></a>], which is consistent with that of previous work. The CVs showed two distinct oxidation peaks at 0.47&nbsp;V and 0.74&nbsp;V on the first cycles in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. S12b</span></span></a>, which were consistent with the dealloying of Na<sub>3</sub>P, and Na<sub>x</sub>Ge [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib46" name="bbib46" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib46"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">46</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib47" name="bbib47" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib47"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">47</span></span></a>]. In the first three cycles, there was almost no change in the redox potential for GeP/SWCNTs in LIBs and SIBs, indicating the Li<sup>+</sup> or Na<sup>+</sup> storage process of the GeP electrode was reversible.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0120">In summary, a unique network structure and conductivity of GeP/SWCNTs endowed by SWCNT<sub>S</sub> ensure the improvement of its mechanical properties, which made it maintain integrity in lithiation and sodiation. The first CE of GeP/SWCNTs was particularly far higher than the GeP electrode for Li<sup>+</sup>/Na<sup>+</sup> storage, and the cycle performance of the GeP/SWCNTs electrode outperformed that of the GeP electrode. Moreover, as concluded in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#appsec1" name="bappsec1" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="appsec1"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Table S1</span></span></a>, the first CE for GeP/SWCNTs composite is outstanding, especially in sodium-ion batteries, compared to other GeP-based materials that have been reported.</div></section></section><section id="sec4"><h2 id="sectitle0090" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusions</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0125">GeP is a novel kind of material with a layered structure, which is in favour of lithium/sodium-storage, but its electrochemical performance is poor. Therefore, in this work, we presented a comprehensive study of the mechanical properties of layered GeP as anode in LIBs and SIBs. GeP nanosheets exhibited an average 110&nbsp;% area expansion after the first lithiation, and an average 128&nbsp;% area expansion after the first sodiation. Nevertheless, the expansions of GeP nanosheets caused obvious cracks or fractures among the active material, binder and collector in charge-discharge cycles, leading to the least desirable first CE. Thus, we developed a strategy to mitigate the stress and strain caused by expansion and enhance the mechanical properties of GeP electrodes in lithiation and sodiation by incorporating SWCNTs. GeP nanosheets were wrapped up by mixing SWCNTs, aiding in the formation of a cohesive network structure. GeP/SWCNTs electrode showed an initial specific capacity of 778/911 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> with a CE of ∼85&nbsp;% in LIBs and a considerable initial specific capacity of 719/793 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> with a CE of approximately ∼90&nbsp;% for SIBs. After 200 cycles, the capacity of 456 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> and 397 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> were still maintained for GeP/SWCNTs electrode in LIBs and SIBs, respectively. GeP/SWCNTs were superior to GeP in terms of cyclic stability and rate capacity.</div></section><section id="sec5"><h2 id="sectitle0095" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0130"><strong>Hailin Shen:</strong> Writing – original draft, Methodology, Funding acquisition, Data curation, Conceptualization. <strong>Yutao Shi:</strong> Software, Data curation. <strong>Weibai Bian:</strong> Funding acquisition, Formal analysis, Data curation. <strong>Huaren Wu:</strong> Data curation. <strong>Yingjun Chen:</strong> Formal analysis, Data curation. <strong>Pinyou Zhao:</strong> Formal analysis, Data curation. <strong>Masashi Kotobuki:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Funding acquisition. <strong>Wei Zhang:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Investigation, Funding acquisition. <strong>Xiaohui Chen:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing, Funding acquisition. <strong>Zhenghui Pan:</strong> Writing – review &amp; editing.</div></section></div><section id="coi0010"><h2 id="sectitle0100" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0135">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ack0010"><h2 id="sectitle0105" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgements</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0140">Financial support from made available on request.</div></section></div><div class="Tail"></div><div><section class="bibliography u-font-serif text-s" id="cebib0010"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar?q=M.-H.%20Zhang%2C%20J.-K.%20Meng%2C%20N.%20Xiao%2C%20R.-W.%20Shao%2C%20X.-J.%20Wu%2C%20P.%20Gao%2C%20Z.%20Shadike%2C%20Y.-N.%20Zhou%2C%20Chemical%20Communications%2C%2058%20(2022)%2010345-10348." 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (1)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S1359836825004299"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Hierarchical array hosts with concave spatial confinement and zincophilic seed mediated growth for dendrite-free Zn metal anode</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Composites Part B: Engineering</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="abspara0010">Uneven distribution problems with Zn electrodeposition have emerged as a major obstacle to the development of Zn-ion batteries. A hierarchical array is proposed in this work to synthesize a three-dimensional Zn anode host, composed of Bi-loaded N-doped carbon triangular plates containing carbon nanotubes (Bi/NC-CNTs@CC), and uniform Zn electrodeposition has been achieved through a synergistic regulation strategy of concave spatial confinement and a “microchannel-filling” zincophilic seed mediated growth. The architecture of evenly arranged arrays contributes to homogenizing the surface electric field and reducing the interfacial polarization due to a geometrical confinement effect. The rationally distributed zincophilic Bi particles can further favor the preferential Zn nucleation, verified by both theoretical calculations and electrochemical measurements. The delicately constructed Bi/NC-CNTs@CC host exhibits a high Coulombic efficiency of 99.9&nbsp;% over 1700 cycles in an asymmetric cell and elongates the Zn plating/stripping lifespan to 8000&nbsp;h after pre-plating 6 mAh cm<sup>−2</sup> of Zn (Bi/NC-CNTs@CC-Zn) in a symmetric cell. Moreover, a full battery assembled by the Bi/NC-CNTs@CC-Zn anode and a MnO<sub>2</sub> cathode demonstrates a high specific capacity of 293.3 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.2&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>−1</sup> and a stable capacity retention of 87.1&nbsp;% over 1000 cycles.</div></div></div></div></li></ul></div></div></section></div><a class="anchor abstract-link anchor-primary" href="/science/article/abs/pii/S0378775325000072"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View Abstract</span></span></a><div class="Copyright"><span class="copyright-line">© 2025 Elsevier B.V. All rights are reserved, including those for text and data mining, AI training, and similar technologies.</span></div></article><div class="u-display-block-from-md col-lg-6 col-md-8 pad-right u-padding-s-top"><aside class="RelatedContent u-clr-grey8" aria-label="Related content"><section class="RelatedContentPanel u-margin-s-bottom"><header id="recommended-articles-header" class="section-title u-h4"><span class="related-content-panel-title-text">Recommended articles</span></h2></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon class="related-content-panel-list-entry-outline-padding text-s u-font-serif" id="recommended-articles-article1-title"><a class="anchor u-clamp-2-lines anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0378775324021001" title="High-temperature in situ stress monitoring of a co-fired electrolyte for metal-supported solid oxide cells"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text"><span>High-temperature <em>in situ</em> stress monitoring of a co-fired electrolyte for metal-supported solid oxide cells</span></span></span></a></h3><div class="article-source u-clr-grey6"><div class="source">Journal of Power Sources, Volume 630, 2025, Article 236147</div></div><div
